PROBLEM: You buy 5 pounds of apples for $3.75. What is the unit rate of a pound of apples?
SOLUTION: Solution: To get the unit rate, we want the amount for one pound of apples; this is when “$$x$$” (apples) is 1. We can set up a ratio: $$\\displaystyle \\frac{5}{{3.75}}=\\frac{1}{x};\\,\\,\\,x=\\.75$$.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: You ride 75km in 2.25 hours. What was your average pace? (km/h)
SOLUTION: Solution: We can use the formula $$\\displaystyle  v = \\frac{s}{t} $$. Plugging in the values gives us $$ v = \frac{75}{2.25} = 33.33 $$. Thus, on average I drove 33.33 km/h.
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: How much money would need to be invested at 2% annual simple interest for 10 years to earn$1200? Use the formula $$\\text{Interest}=\\text{Principle }\\times \\,\\text{Rate}\\,\\times \\,\\text{Time}$$.\n\n
SOLUTION: Solution:\nUsing the formula $$I=Prt$$, solve for $$\\displaystyle P:\\,\\,P=\\frac{I}{{rt}}=\\frac{{1200}}{{\\left( {.02} \\right)10}};\\,\\,\\,\\,P=\\6000$$.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: Maria has saved €48 on her shopping. To earn the same amount of interest, she would have to put €2400 in her savings account for a year. What is the interest rate of her savings account?
SOLUTION: The formula for precentages is as follow: $$\\displaystyle  A = \\frac{G\cdot p}{100} $$. If we plug in the values, we get the following equation: $$ 48 = \\frac{2400 \cdot p}{100} $$. There, it is easy to see that  we get $p = 2\\%$
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: 60 is 20% of\xa0what number? \xa0
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: 15 is 30% of\xa0what number? \xa0
SOLUTION: Solution: We use the formula \\displaystyle\\begin{align} A &= \\frac{G \\times p}{100} \\\\15 &= \\frac{G \\times  30}{100}\\end{align}. And therefore we have $ G = 50 $.
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: The price of a pair of shoes has increased by 15%. The original price of the shoes was$20. What is the new price?  \xa0
SOLUTION: $$\\displaystyle \\begin{array}{l}x=\\20+\\left( {15\\%\\,\\times 20} \\right)\\\\x=\\20+\\left( {.15\\times 20} \\right)\\\\x=\\20+\\3=\\23\\\\x=\\23\\,\\end{array}$$ or\xa0 \xa0$$\\displaystyle \\begin{array}{l}x=\\20\\times \\left( {1+15\\%} \\right)\\\\x=\\20\\times \\left( {1+.15} \\right)\\\\x=\\20\\times \\left( {1.15} \\right)\\\\x=\\23\\,\\end{array}$$ 15% of the original amount $$=15%\\times 20$$, since of = times.\xa0We then need to turn the 15% back into a decimal and add to the original amount. \xa0 The second way we did it was to multiply the original amount (20) by 1.15 (100% + 15%), which added 15% to the original amount before we multiplied.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: The rent of $640 is increased by 5 percent. What is the new rent?   \xa0
SOLUTION: We use the formula $$\\displaystyle A =\ \frac{G \\times p}{100} $$. $$ A = \\frac{640\\times 5}{100}. And therefore $ A = 32 $. We now put all things together and end up having a rent of $640 + 32 = 672$
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: The ratio of boys to girls in your new class is 5:2. The sum of the kids in the class is 28. How many boys are in the class?
SOLUTION: \\require{cancel} \\displaystyle \\begin{align}\\frac{{\\text{boys}}}{{\\text{total in class}}}&=\\frac{x}{{28}}=\\frac{5}{7}\\\\\\\\7x&=5\\times 28=140\\\\\\frac{{\\cancel{7}x}}{{\\cancel{7}}}&=\\frac{{140}}{7}\\\\x&=20\\text{ boys}\\end{align} We know the sum of the numbers in the ratio is 7 (boys and girls: 5 + 2), and the sum of the kids in the class is 28. And we also know the “boys” part of the ratio is 5. We need to set up a proportion with the same things on top or on bottom; our ratios will have “boys” on top and “total in class” on bottom. In other words, we need to see how many boys out of 28 will keep a ratio of 5 boys to 7 total in the class. We can cross-multiply and get $$x=20$$.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: The ratio of distance A to distance B is 3:7, their sum is 60 m. What is distance A?
SOLUTION: Translating the given information into equations, we have $$ A : B = 3 : 7 $$ and $$ A + B = 60 $$. If we rearrange the first equation, we get  $$ A =\ \frac{3\\timesB}{7} $$. Now we can plug in the value for A in the second equation: \\begin{align}\\frac{3\\timesB}{7} + B &= 60\\\\ B \\times  \\frac{10}{7} &= 60\\end{align}. We end up having: $ B= 42 $ and $ A = 18 $.
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: One ounce of solution X contains ingredients a and b in a ratio of 2:3. One ounce of solution Y contains ingredients a and b in a ratio of 1:2. If solution Z is made by mixing solutions X and Y in a ratio of 3:11, then 1260 ounces of solution Z contains how many ounces of ingredient a?
SOLUTION: Solution Z: $$\\begin{array}{c}3x+11x=1260;\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,x=90\\\\3\\times 90=270\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. solution X}\\\\11\\times 90=990\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. solution Y}\\end{array}$$ Let’s work backwards on this problem, and first work with solution Z, since we know there are 1260 ounces of it. It’s good to start with the parts of the problems with numbers first! Since we know the ratio of X and Y is 3:11 in solution Z, we can find the ratio multiplier, and find how much of solutions X and Y are in Z. We see that there are 270 ounces of X and 990 of Y in solution Z. Solution X: $$\\begin{array}{c}2x+3x=270;\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,x=54\\\\2\\times 54=108\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. ingredient a}\\\\3\\times 54=162\\,\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. ingredient b}\\end{array}$$ Solution Y: $$\\begin{array}{c}1x+2x=990;\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,x=330\\\\1\\times 330=330\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. ingredient a}\\\\\\,2\\times 330=660\\,\\,\\,\\text{oz}\\text{. ingredient b}\\end{array}$$ Now we know that there are 270 ounces of solution X in solution Z. We can find out how much of ingredients a and b are in solution X by using a ratio multiplier again (one ounce of solution X contains ingredients a and b in a ratio of 2:3). We see that there are 108 ounces of ingredient a in solution X. We can do the same for solution Y, which contains ingredients a and b in a ratio of 1:2. We see that there are 330 ounces of ingredient a in solution Y. $$108+330=438$$
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: According to the cookbook, 1/2 kg of curd cheese with 20% fat is needed for one dish. However, there is only curd cheese with 10% or 40% fat in the fridge. How many grams of each type should the cook use? (anwer in g)
SOLUTION: In the meal we have 1/2 kg of cheese and 100 g of cheese-fat.  Therefore: $$ C10 + C40 = 500 $$ and $$ 1/10 * C10 + 4/10 * C40 = 100 $$. We can substitute C10 with $ C10 = 1000 - 4 * C40 $. And having: $$ 1000 - 3*C40 = 500 $$. And $ C40 = 500/3 $ and $ C10 = 1000/3 $. #### (333.33 g, 166.67g)
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: You’ve taken four tests in your Algebra II class and made an 89, 92, 78, and 83. The final is worth two test grades. What do you need to make on the final to make an A in the class for the semester?
SOLUTION: \require{cancel} \displaystyle \begin{align}\frac{{89+92+78+83+x+x}}{6}&=90\\\frac{{89+92+78+83+2x}}{{\cancel{6}}}\times \frac{{\cancel{6}}}{1}&=90\times \frac{6}{1}\\342+2x&=540\\2x&=198\\\frac{{2x}}{2}&=\frac{{198}}{2}\\\\x&=99\end{align} The average or mean equation is just adding up all the values, and then dividing by the number of values that we just added up. We have to divide by 6, since we have 4 tests given, and then the final is worth 2 test grades. You have to make a 99 on the final to make an A in the class!
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: In the 1st game you scored 2 goals, in the 2nd game you scored 5 goals, in the 3rd game you scored none and in the 4th and 5th games you scored the same number of goals. How many goals n did you score in the last game if you scored an average of 3 goals per game in the last 5 games in total?
SOLUTION:
We can calculate the average as follow: $$\\displaystyle \\frac{2 + 5 + 0 + n + n}{5}=3$$. This represents the sum of all five values divided by 5, equaling the given average of 3. \n
Multiplying both sides by 5 to eliminate the fraction and simplifying: $$\\displaystyle 7 + 2 \\times n = 15 $$ and therfore $ n = 4 $. #### 4
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM: The sum of the least and greatest of 3 consecutive integers (numbers in a row) is 60. What are the values of the 3 integers?
SOLUTION: \displaystyle \begin{align}n+n+2&=60\\2n+2&=60\\2n&=58\\\frac{{2n}}{2}&=\frac{{58}}{2}\end{align} $$\displaystyle n=29\,\,\,\,\,\,n+1=30\,\,\,\,\,\,n+2=31$$ Again, we assign “$$n$$” to the first number, “$$n+1$$” to the second, and “$$n+2$$” to the third, since they are consecutive numbers. Let’s translate the English into math. The least of the three consecutive numbers is “$$n$$“, and the greatest is “$$n+2$$”. We just need to add the least number and the greatest to get 60. The three consecutive numbers are 29, 30, and 31.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: If you add the predecessor and successor of a number m, you get 52. What is the number m?
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM:
Product of a number and 6 is greater than or equal to 102. Find the number.

A. 15
B. 16
C. 17
D. 14
SOLUTION:
Step: 1
Let the number be n.
Step: 2
n × 6 ≥ 102
[Write the inequality.]
Step: 3
n ≥ 17
[Divide by 6 on both sides.]
Step: 4
So, for the values of n ≥ 17 the inequality is satisfied.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM:
If you add to a number both its neighbours you get 147. What is the number?

A. 39
B. 40
C. 49
D. 59
SOLUTION: We call  x  the desired number. The problem asked for a sum of 3 consecutive numbers: (x-1) + x + (x+1) = 147. This gives us the follwoing simplified equation:   3 * x = 147  and the solution x  is therefore  49.
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM:
The sum of a number and 13 is less than or equal to 7. Find the number.
A. - 6
B. 6
C. 5
D. - 5
SOLUTION:
Step: 1
Let n be the number
Step: 2
Sum of number and 13 = n + 13
Step: 3
n + 13 ≤ 7
Step: 4
n + 13 - 13 ≤ 7 - 13
[Subtract by 13 on both the side]
Step: 5
n ≤ - 6
Correct Answer is : \xa0\xa0- 6
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM:
The triple of a number is 8 less than 23. What is the number? 
A. 3
B. 5
C. 7
D. 9
SOLUTION: We call  x  the desired number. The problem asked for triple of a number, we therefore can write:\n   3 * x = 23 - 8 = 15. After solving this equation for x, we get x= 5.
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM:
If the roots of the quadratic equation x2\xa0+ px + q\xa0 = 0 are 2 and 4, what is the sum of p and q?

This question was previously asked in
PGCIL DT Electrical 13 Aug 2021 Official Paper (NR I)
View all PGCIL Diploma Trainee Papers >
1. 6
2. 2
3. 8
4. -2
SOLUTION:
Option 2 : 2

## Detailed Solution

Concept:

Let us consider the standard form of a quadratic equation,\xa0ax2\xa0+ bx + c = 0

Let α and β be the two roots of the above quadratic equation.

1. The sum of the roots of a quadratic equation are:\xa0α\xa0+\xa0β\xa0= (-b/a)

2. The product of the roots is given by:\xa0α\xa0×\xa0β = (c/a)

Calculation:

The given equation is x2\xa0+ px + q = 0
$\frac{1}{\alpha }$

⇒ 2\xa0+\xa04\xa0= (-p)

⇒ p = -6

again,\xa02\xa0×\xa04 = (q)

⇒ q = 8

∴ Required sum = 8 + (-6) = 2
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: Calculate the missing coefficient and the second solution of the equation $x^2 + px + q = 0 $ given that $q = -3 \quad \text{and} \quad x_1 = -2.$\n\n
SOLUTION:
## Solution

To solve this question we will use Vieta's formulas:  
 egin{align}x_1 + x_2 &= -p \\x_1 \cdot x_2 &= q\end{align}. We know that $q$ and $x_1$ are given. Therefore, we will use the second equation first. Pluggin in the known values we get: $$ -2 \cdot x_2 = -3 \implies x_2 =  rac{3}{2} $$. Now we take the first equation of Vieta and plug in all now known values: $$-2 + \frac32 = - p$$ After solving for p, we get $p = \frac12$. We conclude with: $$p = \frac12, \quad x_2 = \frac32$$
LABEL: Clean

PROBLEM:
When 24 is subtracted from a number, it becomes 7/8 times of the original number, then find 1/12 times of the original number.

1. 24
2. 12
3. 16
4. 18
SOLUTION:
Option 3 : 16

## Detailed Solution

Given:

24 is subtracted from the original number.

Calculation:

Let the number be x.

According to the question,

(x - 24) = 7x/8

⇒ (x - 7x/8) = 24

⇒ x/8 = 24

⇒ x = 24\xa0× 8

⇒ x = 192

According to the question,

1/12 times of the number = (1/12)\xa0× 192

⇒ 1/12 times of the number = 16

∴ 1/12 times of the number is 16.
LABEL: Conta

PROBLEM: The units digit of a three-digit number is 4. If you add this number to the number you get when you reverse its digits, the result is 505. If you subtract the first number from the second one, you get 297. Find the first number.
SOLUTION:
## Solution: Let the first three-digit number be $x = 100a_x + 10b_x + 4.$.
The reversed number is:$y = 100 \cdot 4 + 10b_x + a_x = 400 + 10b_x + a_x.$

According to the problem:
$x + y = 505.$

Substitute the expressions:
$$(100a_x + 10b_x + 4) + (400 + 10b_x + a_x) = 505,$$$$101a_x + 20b_x + 404 = 505,$$$$101a_x + 20b_x = 101.$$

But we have also:
$$y - x = 297,$$$$(400 + 10b_x + a_x) - (100a_x + 10b_x + 4) = 297,$$$$396 - 99a_x = 297,$$$$99a_x = 99,$$$$a_x = 1.$$

Plug in $a=1$ into the first equation:
$$101(1) + 20b_x = 101,$$$$20b_x = 0 \implies b = 0.$$
Thus, the first number is:$$x = 100(1) + 10(0) + 4 = 104.$$
LABEL: Clean
